metadata.titleEn: Analysis data of Mesozoic magmatic rocks in the Nima Gaize area of the central and northern Qinghai Tibet Plateau
metadata.description: This dataset contains zircon U-Pb ages, whole rock geochemistry, and zircon Hf isotope data of intrusive and volcanic rocks exposed in the Nima Geze area of the central and northern Qinghai Tibet Plateau. The data is sourced from the research team led by Zhai Qingguo from the Institute of Geology, Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences. The formation and evolution of the Middle Tethys suture zone is a key focus of Tethys dynamics research. In recent years, with the support of secondary scientific research projects, the team has conducted detailed field geological investigations on the Jurassic Cretaceous magmatic rocks in the Nima Gaize area. Based on the zircon U-Pb dating, whole rock geochemistry, and zircon Hf isotope analysis of these rocks, the formation age of the magmatic rocks in the area (182-68 Ma) was determined to be from the Early Jurassic to the Late Cretaceous. On this basis, combined with whole rock geochemistry and zircon Hf isotope research, analyze the source properties and diagenetic processes of these magmatic rocks. By integrating regional magma big data, we have finely characterized the subduction collision process of the Middle Tethys during this period.
metadata.instructions: File Name: Region+Lithology+Data Type Excel, data acquisition method: Download and open the Office software to use

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used for analyzing Mesozoic magmatic rocks in the northern-central Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: zircon U-Pb dating, Hf isotopic analysis, (MC)-LA-ICP-MS multi-receiver plasma mass spectrometry, whole-rock geochemistry, Sr-Nd isotopic data

Definition.Question: What is zircon U-Pb dating and how is it applied in the analysis of Mesozoic magmatic rocks?
Definition.Answer: Zircon U-Pb dating is a radiometric dating method used to determine the age of zircon crystals found in rocks. In the analysis of Mesozoic magmatic rocks, this method helps establish the formation age of the rocks, which in the Nima-Gaize area of the northern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau ranges from 182 to 68 million years ago, from the Early Jurassic to the Late Cretaceous.

Comparison.Question: How do zircon U-Pb dating and whole-rock geochemistry analysis compare in determining the formation age and source characteristics of Mesozoic magmatic rocks in the central-northern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Zircon U-Pb dating provides precise formation ages for the Mesozoic magmatic rocks, ranging from the Early Jurassic to Late Cretaceous (182 ~ 68 Ma), while whole-rock geochemistry analysis offers information on the source characteristics and petrogenetic processes. Both methods are complementary, with zircon U-Pb dating focusing on temporal aspects and whole-rock geochemistry exploring compositional and process-oriented aspects.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for selecting zircon U-Pb dating and Hf isotopic analysis as key methods for studying Mesozoic magmatic rocks in the central-northern Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Zircon U-Pb dating and Hf isotopic analysis are chosen because they provide accurate age determination and insights into the source nature and petrogenesis of the magmatic rocks. These methods allow researchers to determine the formation age of the rocks (182 ~ 68 Ma) from the Early Jurassic to Late Cretaceous and assess the characteristics of the source regions and the processes involved in rock formation. This information is crucial for understanding the subduction-collision processes of the Neo-Tethys in the region during that period.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of utilizing zircon U-Pb dating and Hf isotopic data in understanding the formation and evolution of the Tethys region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing zircon U-Pb dating and Hf isotopic data can lead to a detailed understanding of the formation ages of magmatic rocks in the Tethys region, providing insights into the subduction-collision processes during the Early Jurassic to Late Cretaceous period. This data can also help analyze the source characteristics and diagenetic processes of these rocks, contributing to the broader understanding of the Tethys's formation and evolution.
